1497360476556218373.text: It’s understandable to want to do more. But we must understand what is at stake. The risks of two nuclear powers going to war are dramatically increased by a no-fly zone. This is unimaginable, and would risk many more civilian casualties than a no-fly zone would save.

1497360475226578944.text: And if Russia retaliated, as they certainly would, our Article 5 obligation would be triggered – and the U.S. would be at war with Russia.

1497360473490169857.text: This would mean the U.S. declaring war on Russia. The same goes for if a NATO ally were to enforce the no-fly zone. They too might have to shoot down Russian jets.

1497360472017977350.text: A no-fly zone is enforced, not declared. It requires our fighter jets to go directly against Russian fighter jets, to get them to stay out of a certain airspace. If the U.S. were to do this, our fighter jets would potentially have to shoot down Russian jets.

1497360470038261763.text:
The U.S. & NATO are united in our support for Ukraine. It's the right thing to do in the face of Russian aggression —but we need to be smart about how we do that.

A no-fly zone seems simple, even the bare minimum to save lives. But let’s talk through what this actually means. 🧵

1430648779384963075.text: Heartbreaking to see so many local folks, including so many kids, unable to get out of Afghanistan. My office has been working on hundreds of similar cases, and it underscores how great the need is to get American citizens, Afghan allies, and partners out.

1430607353045520389.text: I was in middle school when the decision to invade Afghanistan was made and I did not have a say. Now, as a Member of the House Foreign Affairs and Armed Services Committees, I am committed to ensuring we learn the lessons of the last few months, and the past twenty years.

1430607352026341377.text: There are many reasons for the challenges we are seeing in Afghanistan today, most of which predate the current President, and they deserve a fulsome policy debate.

1430607350969344009.text: The United States has a moral obligation to help the Afghan people. We also owe them, and all those who sacrificed, honesty and humility about the real failures in Afghanistan over the past twenty years.

1430607349987827720.text: We must guarantee humanitarian parole, increase the refugee cap & provide assistance to refugees, ensure legal safeguards & funding for organizations that deliver humanitarian assistance, and evacuate as many Americans & vulnerable Afghans as possible before we withdraw.

1430607348729622534.text: And while I am disappointed in the execution of the withdrawal and committed to assessing the policy failures in Afghanistan, right now, I am focused on getting as many people to safety as possible and responding to the humanitarian needs of people in Afghanistan.

1430607347492261891.text: I continue to support and agree with President Biden’s decision to withdraw from Afghanistan. However, I remain incredibly concerned about the ongoing evacuation process in Kabul and the deteriorating humanitarian situation in Afghanistan.

1411409661253799939.text: In 2018, China and Russia successfully lobbied for the Human Rights Upfront Initiative to be disbanded. This was an important initiative to the U.S. that strengthened and prioritized human rights in UN engagements.

1411409660054282242.text: These dues have also diminished our standing at the UN. It creates a leadership vacuum and undermines our ability to push for accountability and reform efforts – including human rights initiatives – at the UN.

1411409659152457733.text: Many developing nations that provide the bulk of peacekeeping troops aren't fully reimbursed for their contributions. These shortfalls amount to tens of millions of dollars each for developing nations like Bangladesh, Ghana, and Tanzania.

1411409658267439105.text: Did you know that Congress established a 25% cap on contributions to #UNPeacekeeping in 1994? Our actual share of funding that we have agreed to at the UN is a little over 27%, meaning we are constantly in debt to the UN. The impact?

1407037691947106313.text: The long-term implications for the CTC are enormous. In April, I sent a letter to @POTUS encouraging him to support making the tax credit permanent — so that we can keep up this progress and support the 5 million kids who will still experience poverty. https://t.co/jLg0Q5Pl2D https://t.co/EXLCfytO6R

1407037689212325888.text:
In #CA53, more than 148,000 kids live in households that will receive the Child Tax Credit — that’s 84% of all the kids in our district. 

44,600 households will receive an average benefit of $2,900. That’s 12,400 kids who will no longer experience poverty.

1407037688495198217.text: Nationwide, the expanded Child Tax Credit is projected to cut childhood poverty in half, lifting 5 million American children out of poverty.

1407037687488450560.text: If you filed your 2020 taxes, you don’t have to do anything to apply. And for the families that didn’t file a 2020 tax return, the IRS created a non-filer tool that will automatically determine your eligibility and get you set up to receive the payments. https://t.co/if10YpNpFm

1407037686637121539.text: Now, starting next month, families across the country will start receiving monthly payments directly into their bank accounts or mailboxes — up to $300 per child per month.

1407037685718474766.text: The #ChildTaxCredit means a tax cut for working families all across the country. As Jeffrey Hoehn of @CLNkids said, “Single mothers know where every penny goes. They just don’t have enough pennies to go around.” That goes for so many working parents in #CA53.

1407037684867022853.text: We say “expanded and improved” because we increased the CTC from $2,000 up to $3,000 per kid per year — and up to $3,600 per kid under 6. And we also made sure more lower-income families are eligible.

1407037683919163392.text: After I was elected, I fought to have the expanded and improved #ChildTaxCredit included in the final package of the American Rescue Plan because of the huge impact it would have for families with kids.

1407037683038314498.text: In San Diego, for all the Fortune 500 companies and mansions on the beach, we also had more than 40% of kids living in households experiencing poverty. That’s unacceptable. And that was before the pandemic.

1407037682103029763.text: As many of you know, one of my top priorities in Congress is ending childhood poverty. Before I was elected, I founded a non-profit coalition dedicating to ending the experience of child poverty in San Diego County.

1382414438674927617.text: An important point was made by the President during his remarks— we’ll continue to work through diplomatic and humanitarian channels to support the people of Afghanistan. This is the appropriate next step as we continue to uphold democracy and human rights.

1382413352270495747.text: I was in middle school when we went to war in Afghanistan. I’m now a Member of Congress, serving on the Armed Services and Foreign Affairs Committees. It feels surreal to react to this news and recognize just how long we have been at war.

1382412500621275146.text: And as someone who represents a proud military community in San Diego, I’ve heard from families with two generations of servicemembers who have served in Afghanistan and two generations of families who have supported and sacrificed with them.

1382412087230627845.text: President Biden visiting Arlington this afternoon underscores the gravity of the choices that the Commander in Chief has to make. And that Congress has abdicated for too long.

1382410018071404544.text: I know this is a complicated day for those who served in Afghanistan—who lost loved ones and still live with the trauma of war. A lot of American soldiers died even as our govt and our people lost faith in the efforts. We should never forget that and never let it happen again.

1382403108152741888.text: Watching @POTUS’s remarks on Afghanistan in my DC office between hearings and votes today. This is a historic moment and it’s clear that the President recognizes the importance of this decision. After 20 years, our longest war is ending, and it’s ending this year.
